review.title: Complexity of Prioritized Default Logics
review.abstract: In default reasoning, usually not all possible ways of resolving conflicts between default rules are acceptable. Criteria expressing acceptable ways of resolving the conflicts may be hardwired in the inference mechanism, for example specificity in inheritance reasoning can be handled this way, or they may be given abstractly as an ordering on the default rules. In this article we investigate formalizations of the latter approach in Reiter's default logic. Our goal is to analyze and compare the computational properties of three such formalizations in terms of their computational complexity: the prioritized default logics of Baader and Hollunder, and Brewka, and a prioritized default logic that is based on lexicographic comparison. The analysis locates the propositional variants of these logics on the second and third levels of the polynomial hierarchy, and identifies the boundary between tractable and intractable inference for restricted classes of prioritized default theories.

sections.text: In standard logic, not all possible ways of resolving conflicts between standard rules are generally acceptable. Criteria that represent acceptable ways of resolving conflicts can be incorporated into the inference mechanism, for example, the specific city in inheritance logic, or they can be given abstractly as a sequence of standard rules. In this article, we examine formalizations of the latter approach in Reiter's standard logic. Our goal is to analyze and compare the computational properties of three such formalizations in terms of their computational complexity: the prioritized standard logic of Baader and Hollunder and Brewka and a prioritized standard logic based on lexicographic comparisons.The analysis localizes the propositional variants of this logic at the second and third levels of the polynomic hierarchy, and identi draws the line between tractable and intractable conclusions for limited classes of prioritized standard theories.

sections.heading: 4.2 Complexity in Syntactically Restricted Cases
sections.text: In this section, we examine the complexity of prioritized standard logic in syntactically limited cases. This topic is related to the investigation of the boundary between traceability and intractability of standard logic without priorities by Kautz and Selman (1991) and Stillman (1990). First, we analyze the case in which the priorities are strict total orders. Then, we complete the complexity analysis by extending the results to arbitrary, strict partial orders. Kautz and Selman analyze the complexity of determining the existence of extensions, careful reflection and valiant reflection on standard theories with the form errors listed in Table 1 (without the prescribed classes) and with objective parts that are sentences of words. In Table 1, the letters a; b; c {may be subscribed to the normal dictionaries, and Theletters p; c; those that set propositional variables.

sections.heading: 4.2.1 Summary
sections.text: Due to the constructive nature of the definitions of preferred extensions in the prioritized standard logic of Brewka and Baader and Hollunder, the construction of the unique preferred extensions of standard theories with absolute priorities can always be reversed if the logical consequence tests in propositional logic are comprehensible (Theorem 4.8.) This is because there is always a unique default that is applied next, and this default cannot be overcome by any default that is applied later. Since Brewka does not take into account the non-normal standard theories, the complexity of this standard logic is much simpler than Reiter's standard logic. For unrestricted priorities, Table 2 summarizes the complexity of j = band j = BH with various syntactical limitations.

sections.heading: 5.2 Complexity in Syntactically Restricted Cases
sections.text: As in Section 4.2, we analyze the complexity of the sequential relationship of lexicographically prioritized standard logic under syntactical constraints.

sections.heading: 5.2.1 Summary
sections.text: The results at the boundary between tractability and intractability for j = L P with strict totals P are summarized in Table 4. In cases where the complexity of the lexicographically prioritized standard logic differs from Reiter's standard logic, the complexity is presented in bold. Table 5 shows where the evidence for the complexity results can be found. The effects of the priorities on the complexity of the decision problems in the non-presupposition normal classes are strongest. If the standard rules in these classes are fully ordered, the unique preferred extensions can be easily found by applying the standard rules in the given order. A more complicated polynomial time decision procedure exists for horn defaults with 1-word objective facts (Theorem 5.22). For this class, the presence of an extension applying a given set of extensions, together with the tried and tested preferred construction, gives a fast decision-making process as shown in Figure 7.

sections.heading: 5.2.3 Tractable Classes
sections.text: Next, we give a restricted, tractable class of prioritized standard theories, for which the individual P-preferred L extensions are preferred, using P as the order in which the application of the standard defaults is attempted. Detailed searching is avoided because there is no need to apply a default. The theorem is given in a general form for each tractable subset of classical proposition logic, such as horn clauses, 2-letter clauses, or 1-letter clauses. Theorems and algorithms are part of the folklore of nonmonotonical reasoning. Theorem 5.21 Let F be a class of formulas that takes the ability to test the S-literary. sections.heading: 6. Related Work on Prioritized Default Reasoning

sections.heading: 7. Conclusions
sections.text: We have presented a thorough analysis of the complexity of three versions of prioritized standard logic, which provides results that place this logic in the polynomial hierarchy, and analyzes the question of intractability versus tractability for syntactically limited classes of standard theories. The main results place the propositional variants of three general formalizations of prioritized standard logic, the logic of Brewka (1994) and Baader and Hollunder (1995), which are based on the semiconstructive definition of extensions, and a formalization based on lexicographic comparisons, at the lower levels of the polynomial hierarchy. Since the first two formalizations are very similar, it is not surprising that polynomial time translations exist between the decision problems of these two formalizations only when the polynomitic time translation of the selection logic and the standard logic of selectivity logic of Reiter exists.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: This research was carried out mainly at the Technical University of Helsinki and the University of Ulm and supported by the SFB 527 of the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft. We are grateful for the generous support of the Finnish Cultural Foundation and the Finnish Academy of Sciences and Letters, who contributed to the completion of this work. We thank the four anonymous reviewers for pointing out some errors and for hints on the restructuring of the article and the inclusion of references to related work in Section 6. Holger Pfeifer provided valuable help with proofreading.

referenceMentions.context: Nonmonotonic logics and related systems for nonmonotonic and default reasoning (Reiter, 1980; Moore, 1985; McCarthy, 1980) were developed for representing knowledge and forms of reasoning that are not conveniently expressible in monotonic logics, like the rst-order predicate logic or propositional logics.

Nonmonotonic logics and related systems for nonmonotonic and default reasoning (Reiter, 1980; Moore, 1985; McCarthy, 1980) were developed for representing knowledge and forms of reasoning that are not conveniently expressible in monotonic logics, like the rst-order predicate logic or propositional logics.
For example, in the kind of reasoning expressed as inheritance networks (Horty, 1994), one network link may say that priests imbibe non-alcoholic beverages only.

The need to incorporate priority information to nonmonotonic logics (Lifschitz, 1985; Brewka, 1989; Ge ner & Pearl, 1992; Ryan, 1992; Brewka, 1994; Baader & Hollunder, 1995) stems from the possibility that two default rules are in con ict.

The need to incorporate priority information to nonmonotonic logics (Lifschitz, 1985; Brewka, 1989; Ge ner & Pearl, 1992; Ryan, 1992; Brewka, 1994; Baader & Hollunder, 1995) stems from the possibility that two default rules are in con ict.

The need to incorporate priority information to nonmonotonic logics (Lifschitz, 1985; Brewka, 1989; Ge ner & Pearl, 1992; Ryan, 1992; Brewka, 1994; Baader & Hollunder, 1995) stems from the possibility that two default rules are in con ict.

The need to incorporate priority information to nonmonotonic logics (Lifschitz, 1985; Brewka, 1989; Ge ner & Pearl, 1992; Ryan, 1992; Brewka, 1994; Baader & Hollunder, 1995) stems from the possibility that two default rules are in con ict.
Speci city as a basis for resolving con icts between defaults has been investigated in the framework of path-based inheritance theories (Horty, 1994).

Preferred subtheories (Brewka, 1989) and ordered theory presentations (Ryan, 1992) do not have as general a notion of defaults as Reiter's default logic, and they can both be translated to prerequisite-free normal default theories of a prioritized default logic (Rintanen, 1999).

Preferred subtheories (Brewka, 1989) and ordered theory presentations (Ryan, 1992) do not have as general a notion of defaults as Reiter's default logic, and they can both be translated to prerequisite-free normal default theories of a prioritized default logic (Rintanen, 1999).

Preferred subtheories (Brewka, 1989) and ordered theory presentations (Ryan, 1992) do not have as general a notion of defaults as Reiter's default logic, and they can both be translated to prerequisite-free normal default theories of a prioritized default logic (Rintanen, 1999).
Also the de nitions of model minimization in conditional entailment (Ge ner & Pearl, 1992) and in prioritized circumscription (Lifschitz, 1985) do not directly support defaults with prerequisites.

In this work we concentrate on Brewka's (1994) and Baader and Hollunder's (1995) proposals for incorporating priorities to default logic, as well as a proposal that uses lexicographic comparison (Rintanen, 1999).

Like earlier work on complexity of nonmonotonic logics (Kautz & Selman, 1991; Stillman, 1990; Gottlob, 1992), the purpose of our investigation is to point out fundamental di erences and similarities between these logics, characterized by polynomial time translatability between their decision problems, and to identify restricted classes of default theories where reasoning is tractable.

The decision problems of propositional default logic are located on the second level of the polynomial hierarchy (Gottlob, 1992), and hence they do not belong to the classes NP or co-NP unless the polynomial hierarchy collapses to its rst level.
First we analyze the computational complexity of two closely related prioritized default logics (Brewka, 1994; Baader & Hollunder, 1995).

These logics are based on the semiconstructive de nition of extensions of default logic (Reiter, 1980): the priorities control the construction of extensions, ruling out those that do not respect the priorities.
We continue by analyzing a prioritized default logic that is based on comparing the Reiter extensions of a default theory by lexicographic comparison (Rintanen, 1999).

Marek and Truszczy nski (1993) introduce a prioritized default logic that is similar to Brewka's (1994) logic. The existence of preferred extensions is not guaranteed in general, but for normal defaults it is. We believe that for normal default theories, the complexity of the Marek and Truszczy nski logic coincides with the complexity of Brewka's logic. Delgrande and Schaub (1997) present a translation from prioritized default theories to unprioritized default theories, so that the extensions of the resulting theories obey the priorities.
Buccafurri et al. (1998) present a knowledge representation language that extends logic programs with priorities, classical
Brewka and Eiter (1998) present the notion of preferred answer sets for extended logic programs.

Principle I is violated by the prioritized default logics that are based on the semiconstructive de nition of extensions (Baader & Hollunder, 1995; Brewka, 1994; Marek & Truszczy nski, 1993), but not by the lexicographic prioritized default logic discussed in Section 5.
However, Principle II is not violated by a closely related prioritized default logic that replaces application with non-defeat (Rintanen, 1999).
Priorities used in translating inheritance networks to prioritized default logic ful ll this requirement (Rintanen, 1999).

The main results place the propositional variants of three general formalizations of prioritized default reasoning, the logics by Brewka (1994) and Baader and Hollunder (1995) that are based on the semiconstructive de nition of extensions, and a formalization that is

An analysis of the complexity of the decision problems in syntactically restricted cases, following earlier work by Kautz and Selman (1991) and Stillman (1990), identi es the e ect of priorities on the boundary between tractability and intractability in the prioritized versions of the decision problems.

An analysis of the complexity of the decision problems in syntactically restricted cases, following earlier work by Kautz and Selman (1991) and Stillman (1990), identi es the e ect of priorities on the boundary between tractability and intractability in the prioritized versions of the decision problems.

metadata.abstractText: In default reasoning, usually not all possible ways of resolving con icts between default rules are acceptable. Criteria expressing acceptable ways of resolving the con icts may be hardwired in the inference mechanism, for example speci city in inheritance reasoning can be handled this way, or they may be given abstractly as an ordering on the default rules. In this article we investigate formalizations of the latter approach in Reiter's default logic. Our goal is to analyze and compare the computational properties of three such formalizations in terms of their computational complexity: the prioritized default logics of Baader and Hollunder, and Brewka, and a prioritized default logic that is based on lexicographic comparison. The analysis locates the propositional variants of these logics on the second and third levels of the polynomial hierarchy, and identi es the boundary between tractable and intractable inference for restricted classes of prioritized default theories.
